awd_titl_txt: PREEVENTS Track 2: Collaborative Research: COEXIST: COnnected EXtremes In Space and Time
awd_abstract_narration:
The project goal is to improve our ability to withstand extreme floods and droughts. A single flood or drought event can cause problems, yet the devastation wrought by a series of back-to-back floods or dramatic swings between drought and flood conditions can be much worse. California, for example, is all too familiar with dangerous mudslides triggered by flash flooding on top of burn scars left over from prior drought conditions. The central U.S. is also no stranger to back-to-back expansive flooding episodes that drive destructive surges down the major rivers. These grouped events seriously test our ability to manage flood and drought and ensure protection of lives and property. Scientists do not fully understand the weather conditions that cause these grouped events. Nor do they know how good we are at forecasting them 2 weeks to 2 months in advance. Experts from insurance, reservoir design and emergency responders will gather with scientists to identify how these grouped events cause problems. This knowledge will then be used to craft the research necessary to support solutions. New scientific discoveries are anticipated about what causes floods and droughts to group together across the U.S. This new knowledge will then be used to develop ways to forecasts these grouped events 2 weeks to 2 months in advance. These new forecasting approaches will support our ability to prepare and reduce impacts. Through supporting enhanced protection of lives and livelihoods this project ultimately strengthens our national welfare and economic competitiveness. In addition to new science and better forecasts the project has a number of other potential benefits. The integration of research and education is central to the project, and will be achieved through the training and career development of the project team and one graduate student. The project is also committed to diversity and inclusion. Participation of underrepresented groups will be broadened through the mentoring of students underrepresented in science each summer. To promote additional scientific research the project will adhere to, and promote, best practices in open, accessible and reproducible science. The project will also engage non-scientists through a series of media interviews, newspaper/TV appearances, and science writing regarding the special risks to humans and environment posed by connected floods and droughts, and strategies to reduce their impacts. 

The work is structured around three objectives: 1) Identify potentially connective regimes and formulate hypotheses about the underlying shared processes by applying statistical models to observation-based datasets of U.S. extreme wet and dry events; 2) Advance the hypotheses by conducting a targeted suite of multi-scale dynamical model experiments for at least six instances of connected events; 3) Understand shared predictability sources by developing and testing a suite of prototype sub-seasonal to seasonal statistical-dynamical forecast systems. Potential contributions include understanding the shared physical processes connecting extreme wet and dry events, demonstrating extended forecast capacity for wet and dry extremes using forecast systems that emphasize connecting processes, and transforming how scientists conceptualize extreme events. Key project outcomes include a physical-process based definition of connected extremes, and a novel generalized research framework that co-advances shared-process understanding and forecast capacity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF Project Outcomes Report (for UCLA-led portion of PREEVENTS Track 2: Collaborative Research: COEXIST: COnnected EXtremes In Space and Time)

 

A)   Key research findings

 

1)    Exploring drivers and trends in the spatiotemporal connectedness of precipitation extremes during the North American Monsoon

During the summer months, the southwestern United States experiences a seasonal monsoon—or seasonal wind reversal leading to precipitation, which is typically associated with thunderstorms (convection). We designed new methods to systematically track spatially organized convective systems and associated extreme precipitation events, understand their drivers, and assess long-term trends. Work will continue past the formal project end date, but we offer preliminary key findings below:

 

  • Extreme precipitation events during the North American Monsoon are primarily associated with organized convective systems, which are characterized by high surface temperatures, a deep planetary boundary layer, and moist mid-levels.

 

  • Between 1980-2020, there has been a trend toward fewer organized convective precipitation extremes but an increase in isolated extreme precipitation events.

 

  • This trend in fewer extremes arising from organized convection has coincided with a strong surface warming trend and large increase in atmospheric dryness (evaporative demand).

 

A manuscript describing this research is currently (as of April 2024) in preparation (Bukowski et al.).

 

2)    How will variations in weather, climate, and vegetation conditions affect windows of opportunity for prescribed fire treatments in the western United States?

We quantified both observed and projected trends in meteorological and vegetation conditions conductive for safe and effective implementation of prescribed fire treatments in the western United States, and how such windows of favorability may change in a warming climate. Prescribed fire, increasingly viewed as a helpful tool to mitigate the risk of catastrophic wildfires and to improve ecosystem health, can typically only take place if ambient environmental conditions fall into a range that is not too extreme (e.g., neither too dry or too wet). Using real-world observations as well as climate model projections, we found that moderate levels of future warming (2°C of warming by 2060) will significantly reduce future opportunities for prescribed fire in most sub-regions. However, we also found that shifts in the seasonality of favorable conditions may open up new 'windows of opportunity' in previously unfavorable seasons (i.e., in winter, especially in northern states). This research demonstrates that complex spatiotemporal patterns of changes in environmental conditions conducive to prescribed fire are likely to emerge—highlighting that there will be no 'one size fits all solution' either from a regional or seasonal perspective, and emphasizing the importance of practices and policies that allow for maximum flexibility.

 

A manuscript describing this research was published in 2023:

Swain, D.L., J.T. Abatzoglou, C. Kolden, K. Shive, D. A. Kalashnikov, D. Singh, and E. Smith. 'Climate change is narrowing and shifting prescribed fire windows in western United States.' Communications Earth and Environment, 4, 340, doi: 10.1038/s43247-023-00993-1, 2023.

  

3)    Quantifying the rising risk of widespread severe flooding in California and developing extreme scenarios for disaster preparedness and climate adaptation

We sought to understand the characteristics and drivers of severe multi-week winter storm sequences in California, and how they may be changing in a warming climate. By embedding a high resolution weather model inside climate model simulations, we found that physically plausible storm sequences (composed of 7-10 or more individual storms in rapid sequence) could bring historically unprecedented precipitation (up to 100 inches over 4 weeks in mountainous regions) and runoff in both present day and warmer future climate scenarios, but that historical climate change has already doubled the likelihood of such an extremely severe storm sequence in California and that large further increases are plausible due to future climate change. We also found that such events are more likely to occur during years characterized by strong El Nino (warm ocean) conditions in the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean. This research has helped form the basis for the 'ARkStorm 2.0' scenario, a joint effort by the U.S. Geological Survey and other agencies/entities to help the region better prepare for the risk of catastrophic flooding in California.

 

A manuscript describing this research was published in 2022:

Huang, X.Y. and D.L. Swain. 'Climate change is increasing the risk of a California Megaflood'. Science Advances, 8, 32, doi: 10.1126/sciadv.abq0995, 2022.

 

B)   Broader impacts and dissemination of research results

Disciplinarily cross-cutting themes in the NSF-funded research described above allowed for direct engagement with scientists well beyond the funded collaborators (including hydrologists, wildfire scientists, and ecologists), responders (water, wildland fire, and emergency managers), and policymakers (including briefings to members of congress, state legislatures, and the White House). Research findings have been directly incorporated into agency decision and rulemaking at regional, state, and federal levels.

 

Additionally, PI Swain incorporated research findings in hundreds of news media interviews, hundreds of social media posts and videos, and dozens of blog posts that reached a general public audience in the tens of millions.
